properties.assessment_comment: Bridge installed in 2020 or 2021.  Bridge span estimated from photos.
properties.dewatering_notes: No dewatering. Stream flows nicely through construction footprint.
properties.velocity_notes: Velocities within the construction footprint are comparable to upstream and downstream.
properties.constriction_notes: Although there is no additional constriction to the channel within the construction footprint, it appears as though the channel upstream was channelized somewhat to align with the inlet of the previous structure and was not widened as part of the project. Underneath the bridge, there is no constriction at all with generous room for channel migration.
properties.substrate_notes: Substrate within the channel footprint is comparable to upstream and downstream with some boulders strategically placed to promote stone lines and break up some of the steeper sections.
properties.riparian_notes: Riparian within the construction footprint is primarily herbaceous with no evidence of shrub or tree planting related to the project.
properties.flow_depth_notes: Natural in filling of the channel has produced stone lines and placed boulders have produced shallow pools suitable for refuge.
properties.stability_notes: Structure appears stable with no evidence of slumping or erosion.
properties.revegetation_notes: Revegetation appears to be primarily herbaceous likely from a clover and grass seed mix
properties.cover_notes: Boulders placed within the construction footprint and natural stone lines have produced areas of refuge with shallow pool cover. There is no overhanging vegetation and no large wood debris with very sparse small wood debris present.

properties.assessment_comment: Culvert was removed by Gitksan Watershed Authorities. Site riprap was buried with dirt and seated with good regrowth of grasses. Shrub planting is planned for this fall.
properties.dewatering_notes: Water is flowing well through construction footprint with no evidence of dewatering
properties.velocity_notes: Velocities through the construction footprint were comparable to riffle-type morphology sections upstream and downstream. Placement of riprap boulders within the wetted channel created localized pockets of reduced velocity suitable for resting.
properties.constriction_notes: Channel widths ranged from 4.5–5m, with wetted width at the time of assessment approximately 4m. The channel did not appear constricted through the construction footprint.
properties.substrate_notes: Channel substrate was composed primarily of cobbles with some strategically placed boulders. Overall composition appeared natural and suitable for the stream.
properties.riparian_notes: Riparian removal to accommodate construction appeared minimal, with shrub planting planned for the fall off  2025. The site was re-vegetating well with a reclamation grass mix and mulch, and much of the armoring rock had been covered with quality topsoil.
properties.flow_depth_notes: Flow depths through the construction footprint appeared suitable, ranging from 5–15cm. Over time, natural stone lines were expected to develop, creating deeper areas as the channel continued to mature.
properties.stability_notes: Site appears stable with ample rock to prevent washouts.
properties.revegetation_notes: Reclamation grasses that were seeded appeared to be growing well, supported by coconut matting and areas where rock had been buried with topsoil. Shrub planting was reportedly planned for the fall 2025.
properties.cover_notes: Strategically placed boulders provided some instream cover, and one piece of woody debris was present at the downstream end of the site. Overhead vegetation within the footprint is expected to provide additional cover as it matures.
properties.maintenance_notes: No maintenance required at the time of assessment however, revegetation activities were not yet complete.

properties.assessment_comment: Overall, the site looks very similar to last year, in good condition with no evidence of any structural issues and the instream portion doing quite well. As there is a large amount of rock rip wrap adjacent to the stream that was not planted the riparian vegetation within the footprint is basically nonexistent. Electrofishing was conducted at sites downstream and upstream of the bridge with fish over 65mm PIT tagged.  eDNA samples were collected as well.
properties.habitat_comment: Channel appears to be maturing well with some deeper sections adjacent to boulders that were placed in the active channel. Stone lines are developing at 2 to 4m intervals. More fish were captured within the construction footprint this year than last year indicating fish are migrating in and habitat is improving.
properties.dewatering_notes: No degrading of the channel noted. Good flow throughout construction footprint.
properties.velocity_notes: Velocities in the construction footprint are similar to upstream and downstream with maturing stone lines and placed boulders, stepping out the gradient to natural conditions
properties.constriction_notes: Width of channel appears similar to upstream and downstream with room for channel migration.
properties.substrate_notes: Substrate is very similar to upstream and downstream with well placed riprap and boulders providing scour and creating pool habitat.
properties.riparian_notes: Basically no riparian regrowth within the construction footprint due to large amount of rip wrap placed.
properties.flow_depth_notes: Flow depths are acceptable with deep sections adjacent to stone lines and placed boulders.
properties.stability_notes: Structure appears stable with no evidence of any movement
properties.revegetation_notes: Revegetation of the site is generally poor due to the large amount of rock placed in the construction footprint and a lack of planting and seeding.
properties.cover_notes: Cover is available adjacent to stone lines and placed boulders were scour and some shallow pools have been created. Fish were captured in these areas within the construction footprint, indicating that they are providing suitable habitat for local fish species.

properties.assessment_comment: Routine effectiveness evaluation. Structure was replaced several years ago and monitoring is ongoing. Electrofishing with fish over 65mm in length PIT tagged,  as well as EDNA sampling was conducted in 2025.
properties.habitat_comment: Overall, the habitat within the construction footprint is maturing nicely with gravel filling within and adjacent to rip wrapped areas. As indicated in past monitoring, the channel under the bridge is slightly constricted by riprap however, stone lines have developed creating overall gradient of approximately 4% with step pools no higher than 15 to 25cm.
properties.dewatering_notes: Stream is flowing nicely through the construction footprint with no evidence of aggregation, or any sign of dewatering
properties.velocity_notes: Velocity within project footprint is slightly faster than naturalized areas upstream and downstream because of the construction from riprap however, overall they do not appear to prevent migration of juveniles larger than approximately 130mm. During higher flow times of the year velocity may be quite higher, however.
properties.constriction_notes: Channel is constricted within the 4 - 5m upstream and downstream of the bridge with channel widths  ranging from 2.5 - 3.4m.
properties.substrate_notes: Substrate is filling in nicely with gravels and cobble/boulder stone lines with a composition comparable to upstream and downstream within natural areas of the stream.
properties.riparian_notes: Overall, the riparian footprint disturbed is quite small and shrub growth from the edges of the footprint is beginning to fill in the upstream and downstream edges.
properties.flow_depth_notes: Flow depth within the construction footprint are comparable to those upstream and downstream in natural areas with some deeper pockets scoured adjacent to stone lines and placed boulders within the channel.
properties.stability_notes: Structure appears stable with no indication of any issues.
properties.revegetation_notes: Adjacent to the bridge there’s only a small amount of herbaceous regrowth in between heavily rip wrapped areas. It is expected that as tsime passes fine substrates will infiltrate the riprap more during high flow events, and that those areas will colonize more with natural herb and shrub species over time.
properties.cover_notes: Placed riprap boulders and developed stone lines have created areas of bubble curtain and shallow pool cover throughout the construction footprint. Overhead cover from vegetation is extremely minimal still however some willow and other shrub regrowth indicates it will improve overtime.

properties.assessment_comment: eDNA samples collected upstream and downstream of the crossing during the monitoring assessment.
properties.dewatering_notes: Remedial works by MoTi in 2019 has backwatered the outlet pool level to match the pipe outlet elevation forming a deep outlet pool downstream. When stream is flowing - there will be continuous flow through the structure with cement/rock baffles present within the pipe.
properties.velocity_notes: Although velocity at the time of assessment was low due to reduced flows, it was expected to exceed the burst swim capacity of all species, including chinook, during high flow conditions. Channel width upstream was up to three times greater, indicating substantially higher discharge during peak flows.
properties.constriction_notes: Channel was significantly constricted due to the concrete armoring along the bottom of the pipe which reduced the effective width from approximately 4m to about 3.5m through the lower third of the structure.
properties.substrate_notes: Five concrete baffles within the structure appeared damaged, likely from high flow events, and were retaining minimal substrate. Only the second baffle from the upstream end was effectively holding material. Water in the outlet pool was turbid, and significant accumulation of fines was expected due to low velocities.
properties.riparian_notes: Does not appear as though there was any riparian planting as part of the remediation works
properties.flow_depth_notes: Depths of flow are very shallow however they are comparable to flow depths currently seen upstream and downstream
properties.stability_notes: The downstream backwatering structures composed of Newbury riffles appeared stable and undamaged since 2019. In contrast, the concrete boulder baffles inside the structure showed evidence of damage likely caused by high flow events following construction.
properties.revegetation_notes: Although unverified, it does not appear as though there was any planting done as part of the project
properties.cover_notes: The deep outlet pool is providing good pool cover for fish
properties.maintenance_notes: The baffles within the structure need to be rebuilt to be the most effective

properties.dewatering_notes: Channel appeared to be maturing well, with beaver activity backing up extended sections and creating high-quality chinook parr rearing habitat, including within the construction footprint.
properties.velocity_notes: Due to all the beaver activity velocities are slow with some riffle sections connecting backwatered areas
properties.constriction_notes: Channel within the riprap directly under the bridge is comparable width to upstream and downstream
properties.substrate_notes: Substrate appears appropriate for stream and comparable within the footprint to upstream and downstream. Primarily fines and gravel.
properties.riparian_notes: Upstream of the structure, numerous felled aspen trees indicated active beaver use. No shrub planting appeared to have been completed as part of the construction, and vegetation regrowth was minimal except along the lower margins of the riprap where natural cottonwood, dogwood, and willow establishment was occurring.
properties.flow_depth_notes: Water depths were reasonable given the minimal flows at the time of assessment. Very shallow riffle areas were present, consistent with expected conditions under low flow.
properties.stability_notes: Structure is stable with no evidence of any deterioration.
properties.revegetation_notes: Rock armoring installed during construction was not planted and remained largely bare of vegetation. Within the construction footprint, some volunteer willow, cottonwood, dogwood, and rose were present, though cover was dominated by grass species likely seeded at the time of construction.
properties.cover_notes: Cover had increased as a result of backwatering from beaver dams and the accumulation of large woody debris created by trees felled through beaver activity.
